The Buddha said:
In the past, incalculable eons ago, there was a great country called Yepa, and its king was called Shiba.
He ruled the country with right Dharma and did not oppress the people.
The king had four thousand ministers, who governed sixty small countries and eight hundred villages.
He had five hundred great white elephants.
The king had twenty thousand wives, but none had a child.
The king himself prayed to the gods and mountains and rivers, and his wife then became pregnant.
The king himself made offerings to his wife, providing her with fine and soft bedding, food, and drink.

The prince served his parents as if serving the heavenly gods. The king built a separate palace for the prince.

Since the prince was young, he has always loved to give alms, to all the people in the world, to the flying birds and running beasts, wishing to enable all sentient beings to always obtain his blessings.
Foolish people are stingy and greedy, unwilling to give alms, foolishly deceiving themselves, of no benefit to themselves. The wise, living in the world, know that giving is a virtue.

Those in the eight directions, above and below who heard of the prince's merits, people from the four directions came from a hundred li away, a thousand li away, and even from ten thousand li away.

Those who wished to get food were fed, those who wished to get clothes were given them, those who wished to get gold, silver, and precious treasures were given them to their satisfaction, not going against their wishes for whatever they sought.
At that time, there was an enemy country that heard that the prince was fond of giving and would not go against anyone's wishes in their requests.
He then gathered his ministers and various Daoist masters to discuss together, saying:

' The prince, upon hearing this, was overjoyed and went out to greet them. He bowed to them as a son would to his father. He then inquired after them:

The eight mendicants said:

People say that the prince is not false.
Now he is the son of gods and humans. What the gods and humans say will never deceive.'
If the prince is truly able to give generously and not go against people's wishes, I wish to beg the prince for the white elephant that walks on lotus flowers.'

The prince then thought to himself:

The ministers in the country, hearing that the prince had given the white elephant as a gift to his enemy, were all greatly shocked. They fell off their beds, feeling sorrowful and unhappy, thinking:

The prince said:

We repent to our father, and by this cause and condition, may our sins be extinguished and our blessings increase, and may we never encounter this again in our future lives.
The prince said to his children:
'In the world, all kindness and love must end in separation. Everything is impermanent, so what can be preserved?
When I attain the unsurpassed and equal Way, I will myself deliver you.'
The two children said to their father:

The brÄhman said:
